semantic_title: Coding for Patients Receiving Diagnostic Services Only
section_path: Section IV > K. Patients receiving diagnostic services only

content.full_text: For patients receiving diagnostic services only during an encounter/visit, sequence first the diagnosis, condition, problem, or other reason for encounter/visit shown in the medical record to be chiefly responsible for the outpatient services provided during the encounter/visit. Codes for other diagnoses (e.g., chronic conditions) may be sequenced as additional diagnoses. For encounters for routine laboratory/radiology testing in the absence of any signs, symptoms, or associated diagnosis, assign Z01.89, Encounter for other specified special examinations. If routine testing is performed during the same encounter as a test to evaluate a sign, symptom, or diagnosis, it is appropriate to assign both the Z code and the code describing the reason for the non-routine test. For outpatient encounters for diagnostic tests that have been interpreted by a physician, and the final report is available at the time of coding, code any confirmed or definitive diagnosis(es) documented in the interpretation. Do not code related signs and symptoms as additional diagnoses. Please note: This differs from the coding practice in the hospital inpatient setting regarding abnormal findings on test results. (Evidence: pg no: 114, L81-L84)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Sequence first the reason chiefly responsible for diagnostic services (Evidence: pg no: 114, L81-L82)
detailed_rules.explanation: The primary code should represent the main reason for the diagnostic services provided during the encounter (Evidence: pg no: 114, L81-L82)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use Z01.89 for routine testing without signs, symptoms, or diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 114, L82)
detailed_rules.explanation: When routine laboratory or radiology testing is performed without any clinical indication, use the specified Z code (Evidence: pg no: 114, L82)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code both Z code and non-routine test reason when performed together (Evidence: pg no: 114, L82-L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: When routine and non-routine testing occur in same encounter, code both the Z code and the clinical reason for non-routine testing (Evidence: pg no: 114, L82-L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code confirmed diagnoses from interpreted diagnostic reports (Evidence: pg no: 114, L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: When diagnostic tests have been interpreted by physician and final report available, code any confirmed diagnoses from the interpretation (Evidence: pg no: 114, L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not code signs/symptoms with confirmed diagnoses from interpretations (Evidence: pg no: 114, L84)
detailed_rules.explanation: When diagnostic interpretation confirms a diagnosis, do not additionally code the related signs and symptoms (Evidence: pg no: 114, L84)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Determine if encounter is for diagnostic services only
Step 2: Identify the chief reason for diagnostic services
Step 3: Determine if testing is routine or has clinical indication
Step 4: For routine testing without indication, use Z01.89
Step 5: For clinical indication, code the reason
Step 6: If combined routine and non-routine, code both
Step 7: If interpretation available, code confirmed diagnoses
Step 8: Exclude related symptoms when diagnosis confirmed
